awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Quantum Complexity, Chaos, and Implications for Analog Quantum Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum technology is the next frontier in the information revolution that powers the nation's economic engine.  Machines that process information using the microscopic laws of quantum physics can solve critical problems that are intractable with even the most powerful supercomputers, such as design of new high tech materials and pharmaceuticals.  A general purpose quantum computer is still years in the future, but current quantum technology is now sufficiently advanced for private companies and government agencies to pursue the development of special purpose "quantum simulators" that can be applied to select problems. Unfortunately, the operation of such machines can be very sensitive to noise and imperfection, in a manner closely analogous to the "butterfly effect" whereby even the smallest disturbance (metaphorically, the flap of a butterfly's wing) can affect the predictive power of weather forecasts. This project seeks to better understand the tradeoff between a quantum simulator's power to solve hard computational problems, and the extreme fragility of its predictions when subject to noise and imperfections. Such understanding will be essential for the successful application of quantum technology to problems in science and engineering.

Quantum simulation requires access to highly entangled many body systems whose dynamics are complex. It has long been a concern that such systems exhibit "quantum chaos" which will make any large scale quantum simulation hypersensitive to imperfections. Yet, at the same time it is argued that requirements for a special purpose quantum simulation are less stringent than for universal digital quantum computing. This, then, is the tension at the heart of quantum simulation: Can one have the complex dynamics needed to access massively entangled states, and at the same time have a reliable device that is not rendered inoperable by hypersensitivity? In short: Can one trust the output of a non-trivial quantum simulator? The proposed research will put those questions to the test in experiments with a quantum simulator based on the spins of individual cesium atoms. This test bed provides access to state-of-the-art control and diagnostics, and offers the ability to drive and observe a nearly unlimited variety of complex dynamics, including many of the paradigmatic models of analog quantum simulation currently explored elsewhere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:  Quantum Information Science is an interdisciplinary subject that studies how unique quantum physics at the atomic scale can be used to process information for application in advanced computing, communication, and sensing. Currently devices are imperfect, and we cannot control them sufficiently to correct errors that might occur.  As such, the architecture used to process information may be subject to instabilities, and become unreliable. This grant was a joint theory-experimental project to explore the realibility of such devices in the face of an unexpected source of errors -- chaos.   Chaos, familar in the so-caller butterfly effect, whereby the flutter of a butterfly can affect our ability to predict the weather, occurs at the quantum level as well.  In this grant we studied how quantum chaos and other  related dynamical instablilties affect the realiability of quantum information processors.

Intellectual Merit:  Quantum complexity lies at the heart of modern physics and plays important roles in phenomena ranging from materials to quantum gravity. Meanwhile, on the frontiers of information technology, quantum complexity is the resource that allows quantum computers to outperform classical devices. Both come together in the field of quantum simulation, where one seeks to use a controlled quantum system to simulate phenomena that cannot be modeled classically.  We found that this complexity can also led to instabilities which make devices unreliable.  Examples of key outcomes include:

  • Implementation and study of a small, highly accurate quantum (SHAQ) processor based on individual cesium atoms, as a platform to study the effects of dynamical instabilities.
  • A new framework tested on the SHAQ platform to characterize the performance of quantum simulators based on its macroscopic vs. microscopic character. 
  • New understanding of how chaos affects the reliability of the output of analog quantum simulation. 
  • A prediction and experimental verification of how dynamical instablities can arise in the standard algorithms for quantum simulation.
  • A prediction of a new state of matetr -- a Floquet time-crystal that is intimately relatly the the dynamical instabilities predicted above.

Broader impacts: 

EDUCATION AND TRAINING: Significant broad impact accrued from the recruitment and training of future scientists. The project provided dissertation topic 2 PhD students at the University New Mexico who successfully defened. This grant also provided avenues of research for postdocs funded through an NSF Focused Research Hub in Theoretical Physics (FRHTP), and annual NSF-REU opportunities for visiting undergraduates. These students & postdocs were involved in all aspects of the project, including research, collaboration, and dissemination of results.

SYNERGISTIC ACTIVITIES: The research took place within the broader context of a decades long collaboration between the PIs, in an environment where the artificial separation of theory and experiment is absent and where both senior and junior participants interact freely across institutional boundaries. The PIs collaboration is a cornerstone of the Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC), home of the NSF FRHTP in Quantum Information Science. The PIs research groups participate in the full spectrum of CQuIC activities, including weekly group meetings, CQuIC seminars, and research retreats. In this way, the proposed project will impact a much broader group of students, postdocs and faculty at the University of New Mexico, the University of Arizona, as well as CQuIC partners at Sandia, Los Alamos National Labs, and other institutions.
